messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 67 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On the Complexity of CSP-based Ideal Membership Problems

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider the Ideal Membership Problem (IMP for short), in which we are given real polynomials f0,f1,‚Ä¶,fksubscriptùëì0subscriptùëì1‚Ä¶subscriptùëìùëòf_{0},f_{1},\dots,f_{k} and the question is to decide whether f0subscriptùëì0f_{0} belongs to the ideal generated by f1,‚Ä¶,fksubscriptùëì1‚Ä¶subscriptùëìùëòf_{1},\dots,f_{k}. In the more stringent version the task is also to find a proof of this fact. The IMP underlies many proof systems based on polynomials such as Nullstellensatz, Polynomial Calculus, and Sum-of-Squares. In the majority of such applications the IMP involves so called combinatorial ideals that arise from a variety of discrete combinatorial problems. This restriction makes the IMP significantly easier and in some cases allows for an efficient algorithm to solve it. The first part of this paper follows the work of Mastrolilli [SODA‚Äô19] who initiated a systematic study of IMPs arising from Constraint Satisfaction Problems (CSP) of the form CSP‚Äã(Œì)CSPŒì\textsc{CSP}(\Gamma), that is, CSPs in which the type of constraints is limited to relations from a set ŒìŒì\Gamma. We show that many CSP techniques can be translated to IMPs thus allowing us to significantly improve the methods of studying the complexity of the IMP. We also develop universal algebraic techniques for the IMP that have been so useful in the study of the CSP. This allows us to prove a general necessary condition for the tractability of the IMP, and three sufficient ones. The sufficient conditions include IMPs arising from systems of linear equations over ùñ¶ùñ•‚Äã(p)ùñ¶ùñ•ùëù\mathsf{GF}(p), pùëùp prime, and also some conditions defined through special kinds of polymorphisms. Our work has several consequences and applications. First, we introduce a variation of the IMP and based on this propose a unified framework, different from the celebrated Buchberger‚Äôs algorithm, to construct a bounded degree Gr√∂bner Basis. Our algorithm, combined with the universal algebraic techniques, leads to polynomial-time construction of Gr√∂bner Basis for many combinatorial problems. Second, we also study a recently posed question by O‚ÄôDonnell [ITCS‚Äô17] on the bit complexity of sum-of-squares (SOS) proofs and their automatizability. We prove that for almost all the CSP-based ideals SOS proofs are automatizable which improves upon the result of Raghavendra and Weitz [ICALP‚Äô17]. Furthermore, in the case where the IMP part is well behaved, we propose automatizable SOS proofs of nonnegativity with much relaxed degree restrictions. Finally, we provide a unifying framework that studies (construction of) theta bodies of combinatorial problems through the universal algebra of the constraint languages and present several positive results for problems such as Stable Set, Binary Matroids, H-Coloring, Min/Max Ones, and Strict CSPs.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 67 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 67"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Proof complexity meets algebra",
        "Constraint satisfaction problem and universal algebra",
        "The constraint satisfaction problem and universal algebra",
        "Polymorphisms, and how to use them",
        "Lower bound on hilbert‚Äôs nullstellensatz and propositional proofs",
        "Gr√∂bner bases",
        "Ideal membership problem and a majority polymorphism over the ternary domain",
        "Ideal membership problem for boolean minority",
        "Bruno buchberger√É¬¢s phd thesis 1965: An algorithm for finding the basis elements of the residue class ring of a zero dimensional polynomial ideal",
        "A dichotomy theorem for nonuniform csps",
        "Towards a dichotomy theorem for the counting constraint satisfaction problem",
        "Classifying the complexity of constraints using finite algebras",
        "A course in universal algebra, volume 78 of Graduate Texts in Mathematics",
        "Good degree bounds on nullstellensatz refutations of the induction principle",
        "Sums of squares of real polynomials",
        "Using the groebner basis algorithm to find proofs of unsatisfiability",
        "Characterising tractable constraints",
        "Ideals, varieties, and algorithms: an introduction to computational algebraic geometry and commutative algebra",
        "The membership problem for unmixed polynomial ideals is solvable in single exponential time",
        "Efficient computation of zero-dimensional gr√∂bner bases by change of ordering",
        "The computational structure of monotone monadic SNP and constraint satisfaction: A study through datalog and group theory",
        "Improved approximation algorithms for maximum cut and satisfiability problems using semidefinite programming",
        "A new semidefinite programming hierarchy for cycles in binary matroids and cuts in graphs",
        "Theta bodies for polynomial ideals",
        "Tseitin‚Äôs tautologies and lower bounds for nullstellensatz proofs",
        "The ellipsoid method and its consequences in combinatorial optimization",
        "Approximation of minimum cost homomorphisms",
        "Bi-arc digraphs and conservative polymorphisms",
        "Die frage der endlich vielen schritte in der theorie der polynomideale",
        "√úber die darstellung definiter formen als summe von formenquadraten",
        "Ueber die theorie der algebraischen formen",
        "√úber die vollen invariantensysteme",
        "Closure properties of constraints",
        "Representing and solving finite-domain constraint problems using systems of polynomials",
        "The approximability of constraint satisfaction problems",
        "Conjunctive-query containment and constraint satisfaction",
        "On lp-based approximability for strict csps",
        "Semidefinite representations for finite varieties",
        "On the shannon capacity of a graph",
        "Semidefinite programs and combinatorial optimization",
        "The complexity of the ideal membership problem for constrained problems over the boolean domain",
        "Membership in plynomial ideals over Q is exponential space complete",
        "The complexity of the word problems for commutative semigroups and polynomial ideals",
        "Algebras, lattices, varieties, volume 383",
        "The arithmetic-geometric inequality, inequalities (proc. sympos. wright-patterson air force base, ohio, 1965)",
        "SOS is not obviously automatizable, even approximately",
        "Congruence relations in semi-lattices",
        "An explicit construction of distinguished representations of polynomials nonnegative over finite sets",
        "Exploiting algebraic structure in sum of squares programs",
        "Interpolation and approximation by polynomials, volume 14",
        "On the complexity of semidefinite programs",
        "The two-valued iterative systems of mathematical logic. number 5 in annals of math.",
        "An algorithm for sums of squares of real polynomials",
        "Toward a dichotomy for approximation of h-coloring",
        "On the bit complexity of sum-of-squares proofs",
        "An exact duality theory for semidefinite programming and its complexity implications",
        "Lower bounds for the polynomial calculus",
        "Constructive aspects of noetherian rings",
        "The complexity of satisfiability problems",
        "Constructions in algebra",
        "Improved approximations of packing and covering problems",
        "Clones in universal algebra",
        "Semidefinite programming and arithmetic circuit evaluation",
        "Constraints, Varieties, and Algorithms",
        "Polynomial proof systems, effective derivations, and their applications in the sum-of-squares hierarchy",
        "Nonlinear optimization techniques applied to combinatorial optimization problems",
        "A proof of CSP dichotomy conjecture"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 67 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On the Complexity of CSP-based Ideal Membership Problems, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
